message_1:
Consider a two-player game in which players take turns removing marbles from a pile. In this game, each player can remove 1, 2, or 3 marbles in each turn. The player who removes the last marble wins the game. 

If there are 20 marbles in the pile at the beginning of the game, and Player 1 goes first, how many possible game outcomes are there?
message_2:
To find the number of possible game outcomes, we can use dynamic programming. Let's define a function F(n) as the number of possible game outcomes when there are n marbles left in the pile. We can express F(n) in terms of F(n-1), F(n-2), and F(n-3), since a player can remove 1, 2, or 3 marbles in each turn.

Base cases:
F(0) = 0 (no marbles left)
F(1) = 1 (only one possible outcome: Player 1 takes the last marble)
F(2) = 2 (two possible outcomes: Player 1 takes 1 marble and Player 2 takes the last marble, or Player 1 takes both marbles)
F(3) = 4 (four possible outcomes: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 2; P1 takes 1, P2 takes 1, P1 takes 1; P1 takes 2, P2 takes 1; P1 takes all 3 marbles)

Recursive formula:
F(n) = F(n-1) + F(n-2) + F(n-3)

Now we can calculate F(20) using the recursive formula:

F(4) = F(3) + F(2) + F(1) = 4 + 2 + 1 = 7
F(5) = F(4) + F(3) + F(2) = 7 + 4 + 2 = 13
F(6) = F(5) + F(4) + F(3) = 13 + 7 + 4 = 24
...
Continue this process until we reach F(20).

F(20) = F(19) + F(18) + F(17) = 6728

So there are 6728 possible game outcomes when there are 20 marbles in the pile and Player 1 goes first.
